posts.cooked:
Hello,

I’m mostly a Pathplanner novice and have a few questions on setup and path configuration:

In the robot config menu, I’m inputting the metrics for our robot and the calculated Max Linear Acceleration value continues to stay red unless I enter an artificially large number in the true max drive speed field.  Red usually indicates ‘bad’, so I’m wondering what I need to do to correct this.  Putting in fake values doesn’t seem like it should be the right approach.

In the robot config menu, I’m inputting the metrics for our robot and the calculated Max Linear Acceleration value continues to stay red unless I enter an artificially large number in the true max drive speed field.  Red usually indicates ‘bad’, so I’m wondering what I need to do to correct this.  Putting in fake values doesn’t seem like it should be the right approach.

Control lengths - I looked through the docs and couldn’t really find a good description (for me) of what these do.  The heading of a waypoint controls the direction of the robot as it passes through that waypoint, but what do the control points do?  What impact does changing the length have?

Control lengths - I looked through the docs and couldn’t really find a good description (for me) of what these do.  The heading of a waypoint controls the direction of the robot as it passes through that waypoint, but what do the control points do?  What impact does changing the length have?

Thanks for any input on this!

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: With control length, you can adjust the waypoints the robot will pass through on its way to the target and shape its path. This allows for smoother transitions and helps the robot avoid obstacles if there are any in its way. For example we have this path to avoid collusion to reef.

Isn’t obstacle avoidance done with waypoints on a path?

Do control points specify how far the robot will try to stay traveling at a specific heading?

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
PKopf:

Isn’t obstacle avoidance done with waypoints on a path?

yes control length helps too you can change path’s curve with control lengths.  It can also sometimes be used to create physically accurate paths.

PKopf:

Do control points specify how far the robot will try to stay traveling at a specific heading?

Control points only adjust curve of the path.

Awesome, thanks!!!

Anyone have input on question #1 above?

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: Can you take a screenshot of configs and your value when you type?

Here you go!:

image 1036×708 30.4 KB

image 1036×708 30.4 KB

image 1036×708 30.4 KB

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: are you sure wheel radius, gearing and COF correct? Also did you test your max true drive speed? (Looks like your gearing is too low is it real?)
Yes, just confirmed that the gearing us correct = 4:1.

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
Did you test your max drive speed? image 878×352 29.7 KB

image 878×352 29.7 KB

image 878×352 29.7 KB
No, we are using the 85% of motor free speed estimation.

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: If all the values are correct, there is nothing to change. PathPlanner calculates based on the values you input. As a last resort, you could increase the drive current limit, but I don’t recommend it.
Any idea why max linear acceleration is red?  I’m not really sure what that indicates.

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked:
PKopf:

I’m not really sure what that indicates.

It indicates your calculated acceleration is too low. But you can still operate your autonomous routines. These values are used for estimating the path time. It does not affect the code.

I noticed that for some values of max speed the max linear acceleration drops down to zero, which doesnt make sense to me, and if I recall correctly won’t allow the optimizer to run correctly.

But if there is no impact onnthe actual code created based on this value then I guess all is well.

Thanks for your help!
